title: Secondary Malignancies
summary: Radiation-induced secondary malignancies are a rare but serious late effect of radiation therapy, typically occurring 5-30 years after treatment with risk factors including age at exposure, dose, and genetic predisposition.

content.text: The absolute risk of secondary malignancy is approximately 1 in 1000 patients per year of follow-up. Risk is highest in children and young adults, with solid tumors typically occurring 10-30 years post-treatment and hematologic malignancies within 5-10 years.

Breast cancer (following chest irradiation for Hodgkin lymphoma), thyroid cancer (following neck irradiation), lung cancer (following chest irradiation), sarcomas (within radiation fields), and acute leukemia (dose-dependent, peaks at 5-9 years).

Risk reduction strategies include minimizing radiation dose and volume, avoiding radiation in young patients when possible, and implementing long-term surveillance protocols based on radiation sites and patient age at treatment.
The benefit-risk ratio strongly favors radiation therapy for most cancer patients, as the risk of secondary malignancy is far outweighed by the benefit of curing the primary cancer.
